div1.head: Book Review: Walter Reed and Yellow Fever, September 1906
div1.p:
Walter Reed and Yellow Fever. By Howard A.
Kelly, Professor of Gynaecological Surgery,
Johns Hopkins University. Pp. xvi--293. New
York: McClure, Phillips & Co. 1906.

A delightful and timely book. We say timely,
particularly, because it seems to us that by popular-
izing the knowledge of Reed's great achievement in
identifying the stegomyia fasciata as the carrier of
the infection of yellow fever, whereby a great ad-
vance has been made towards the entire eradication
of the scourge, the public which has benefited so
largely and will benefit so much more largely, from
this work, ought to be stimulated to do its share
in raising the necessary funds for the Walter Reed
Memorial, which, as we understand from the report
of the committee recently issued, still lacks some
$5,000. It can only be attributed to lack of infor-
mation that the great lay public leaves the major
portion of a fund raised to honor the memory of a
man who has conferred an everlasting benefit on it,
and to assist those he has left behind, to be pro-
vided by the medical profession to which he be-
longed. It is to be hoped that this work, therefore,
will reach a large number of lay readers and will
have a due effect.

Dr. Kelly has executed his self-imposed task with
that conscientious thoroughness that characterizes
his work of whatever kind. He introduces us to
Reed's early life and training, from which we may
learn the lesson that, however advantageous they
may be, congenial and contributory surroundings in
early life are by no means essential for the produc-
tion later of scientific researches of the highest
character. The beginning of his career as a scien-
tist--his earlier years were spent as a military med-
ical officer living a frontier life which is scarcely
conducive to the pursuit of scientific reasearch--
dates from his assignment to duty at Baltimore in
1890. Dr. William Welch has provided Dr. Kelly
with an account of his work at the Johns Hopkins
University and Hospital.

We cannot refrain from quoting the following
passage concerning the necessity for adequate spec-
ialized training for Army Medical officers in time of
war. The evil of supposing that the best profes-
sional man necessarily makes the best army medical
officer, and the still greater evil of considering any
professional man, who can obtain sufficient influence
good enough to hold a medico-military position are
well illustrated in the following passage:

In 1898, when the Spanish-American war broke
out, Dr. Reed became extremely anxious to hold
some responsible position in charge of sick soldiers.
He knew that his experience peculiarly fitted him to
do this work, since he was familiar with practical
matters, such as the condition of the army, the rou-
tine of getting supplies, the manner of preserving
the health of the soldiers, and all questions of gen-
eral management, which were unknown to the ci-
vilian physicians and political doctors appointed to
hold responsible positions over him. He made a
strong effort to secure some such appointment, for
which years of army work had so admirably fitted
him, only to be chagrined and distressed when men
with political influence were preferred, while he
and other army surgeons were relegated to other
unimportant positions. The records of our camps
during the Spanish-American war afford, indeed, a
valuable object lesson on the evils of allowing mat-
ters in which human safety depends upon technical
knowledge and specialized training to be governed
by political interest. For, not only is human life,
under such conditions, at the mercy of ignorance,
indifference, and greed, but the very men whose
hands are tied by political usurpation of authority
which should be theirs, are liable to undeserved
blame for the evils they have striven to prevent,
and our credit as a nation suffers in consequence.

No one felt this injustice more keenly than Dr.
Reed; and in a conversation with a friend soon after
the war was over, he spoke with extreme sadness of
the fact that by such mismanagement on the part of
the Secretary of War and others who should know
better, the Army Medical Corps had been subjected
to censure which it did not deserve. To use his own
words, “The Army Medical Corps has received a
black eye because of the neglect and incompetence
of men who did not really belong to it.”

The civilian has to deal with disease and injury
from a purely individualistic standpoint. That very
training unfits him for the special requirements of
the army medical service. As a matter of fact, an
average professional man of long military experience
is far more efficient as a military medical officer in
time of war than the best civilian that the profes-
sion can offer. Expert clinicians, expert surgeons,
expert sanitarians may with advantage be attached
to the forces to give their special aid in individual
cases; but to preserve the efficiency of the fighting
machine en bloc, the specialized training of the
army medical officer is absolutely essential.

We have already devoted more space to this re-
view than we are justified in doing, so we can but
briefly enumerate the other topics dealt with: The
History of Yellow Fever in the Past; Insects and
Diseases; Work in Yellow Fever; Practical applica-
tion of the Mosquito Theory; Value of Reed's
Work to the World; Life after Return from Cuba,
and Death, 1901-1902; and finally, Other Members
of the Yellow Fever Commission in which Carroll,
Lazear, and Agramonte receive recognition. It is
satisfactory to note also that due credit is given
(pp. 113-119) to the initial work of Dr. Carlos J.
Finlay, of Havana, whose hypothetical suggestion
of the mosquito as the agent of transmission of
yellow fever (1881) is too apt to be overlooked, as
is often the case with valuable suggestive working
hypotheses suggested by thinkers which serve as
ladders whereby the practical experimentalists
climb.

The book is well got up and is illustrated by por-
traits of Reed (at various ages), Finlay, Carroll, La-
zear, Agramonte, etc.
